newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesia sees 1997 inflation below six percent.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia sees 1997 inflation below six percent.

text.p: Indonesia on Wednesday welcomed a fall in inflation during June, and said it expected the year-on-year rate to fall below six percent in calendar 1997.
"Inflation in June fell 0.17 percent. This is very positive for our economy. I think inflation in calendar 1997 will be below six percent," Planning Minister Ginanjar Kartasasmita said.
Figures released earlier showed that Indonesia's consumer price index (CPI) fell 0.17 percent month-to-month in June, after a rise of 0.19 percent in May.
The year-on-year rate slipped to 4.98 percent, compared with 5.08 percent in May.
Indonesia posted an inflation rate of 6.47 percent for the 1996 calendar year against 8.64 percent in 1995.
"Low inflation means our economic development is sound. It can boost our economic growth," Ginanjar said.
Central Bank Governor Sudradjad Djiwandono reiterated that reining in inflation was the main aim of economic policy-makers because lower inflation would allow interest rates to decline.
"The important thing on monetary policy is to get inflation lower and lower. Low inflation will enable us to cut interest rates further," he said.
Ginanjar also said the government would continue trying to trim its current account deficit.
The World Bank has warned Indonesia's current account deficit is likely to swell to $10.1 billion, or four percent of GDP, in fiscal 1997/98 (April-March) from $8.82 billion in 1996/97.
